title: VolatileCalc
summary: VolatileCalc provides solution models for the rhyolite–H2O–CO2 and basalt–H2O–CO2 systems at magmatic temperatures and pressures below 5000 bar. The models are coded as macros written in Visual Basic for Applications, for use within Microsoft Excel . The series of macros, entitled VolatileCalc, can calculate the following: (1) Saturation pressures for silicate melt of known dissolved H2O andCO2 concentrations and the corresponding equilibrium vapor composition; (2) open- and closed-system degassing paths (melt and vapor composition) for depressurizing rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (3) isobaric solubility curves for rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (4) isoplethic solubility curves (constant vapor composition) for rhyolitic and basaltic [...]
body:
VolatileCalc provides solution models for the rhyolite–H2O–CO2 and basalt–H2O–CO2 systems at magmatic temperatures and pressures below 5000 bar. The models are coded as macros written in Visual Basic for Applications, for use within Microsoft Excel . The series of macros, entitled VolatileCalc, can calculate the following: (1) Saturation pressures for silicate melt of known dissolved H2O andCO2 concentrations and the corresponding equilibrium vapor composition; (2) open- and closed-system degassing paths (melt and vapor composition) for depressurizing rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (3) isobaric solubility curves for rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (4) isoplethic solubility curves (constant vapor composition) for rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (5) polybaric solubility curves for the two endmembers and (6) endmember fugacities of H2O andCO2 vapors at magmatic temperatures. The output agrees well with the published solution models and experimental data for silicate melt–vapor systems for pressures below 5000 bar.

Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms):

VolatileCalc

Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)):

2.0

Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism of the model (e.g., system dynamic, agent based model, machine learning), preferably accompanied by relevant keywords):

VolatileCalc provides solution models for the rhyolite–H2O–CO2 and basalt–H2O–CO2 systems at magmatic temperatures and pressures below 5000 bar. The models are coded as macros written in Visual Basic for Applications, for use within Microsoft Excel . The series of macros, entitled VolatileCalc, can calculate the following: (1) Saturation pressures for silicate melt of known dissolved H2O andCO2 concentrations and the corresponding equilibrium vapor composition; (2) open- and closed-system degassing paths (melt and vapor composition) for depressurizing rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (3) isobaric solubility curves for rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (4) isoplethic solubility curves (constant vapor composition) for rhyolitic and basaltic melts; (5) polybaric solubility curves for the two endmembers and (6) endmember fugacities of H2O andCO2 vapors at magmatic temperatures. The output agrees well with the published solution models and experimental data for silicate melt–vapor systems for pressures below 5000 bar.

Originator(s) (Name(s) of the model developer(s)/author(s)):

Jacob B Lowenstern

Contact Name(s) and Email Address(es) (Names of person(s) responsible for maintenance of the model along with their email):

Jacob B Lowenstern (jlwnstrn@usgs.gov)

Release Date (Date model was originally released (YYYYMMDD, YYYYMM, YYYY)):

2002

Last Update (Date of last update (YYYYMMDD, YYYYMM, YYYY)):

Organization(s) (Organization(s) that produced, funded, or partnered on the creation of this model):

USGS

Mission Area (USGS mission area with which this model most clearly aligns. https://www.usgs.gov/science/mission-areas):

Natural Hazards

License (OSI-approved (Open-Source Initiative) license (see https://opensource.org/licenses)):

Model Citation (How to cite the model  (e.g., Software Release citation). For example, Doe, J.S., Sea Turtle Cuteness Model, 2020, U.S. Geological Survey, https://doi.org/xxxxx)):

Identifier (Location where the model is posted or published (e.g. PID or DOI)):

Language (Computer language or platform used for programming (e.g., Fortan, R, Python)):

Microsoft Excel

References (References (where the model has been cited, outputs, data release):

Newman, S., Lowenstern, J.B., 2002, VolatileCalc: a silicate melt-H2O-CO2 solution model written in Visual Basic for Excel: Computers and Geosciences vol. 28 no. 5, pp. 597-604.

Resources (Resources (how to use the model, where to download it, related publications, other webpages about the model (in other catalogs), USGS webpage):

Download VolatileCalc: https://volcanoes.usgs.gov/observatories/yvo/jlowenstern/other/software_jbl.html

Image (URL for an image that best represents the model, title of image, alternate text, URL of source):

Title: Examples of output from VolatileCalc. Isobars represent locus of values for dissolved H2O and CO2 in rhyolitic melt in equilibrium with H2O-CO2 vapor at 800°C and selected pressures. Similarly, isopleths represent locus of rhyolitic melt compositions in equilibrium with given vapor compositions (20, 50 and 80 mol% H2O shown here) at 800°C.

Alternate Text: Line graph with 'Wt.% H2O dissolved in melt' on the x axis and 'PPM Co2 dissolved in melt' on the y axis.

https://volcanoes.usgs.gov/observatories/yvo/jlowenstern/other/NewLow.pdf
